demos.requirements: solution evaluation, comparison of multiple options
demos.template:
# Solution Evaluation & Option Comparison Template

## 1. Executive Summary
- Brief purpose of the evaluation (1–3 sentences)
- Top-line recommendation (best option and why)
- Key trade-offs and risks

## 2. Purpose, Scope & Context
- Objective of the evaluation
- Scope (what is included / excluded)
- Time horizon and constraints
- Key stakeholders

## 3. Options Overview
- Option A: short name
  - One-line description
  - Core features / scope
- Option B: short name
  - One-line description
  - Core features / scope
- Option C: ...
- (Add as many options as needed)

## 4. Evaluation Criteria & Weighting
- List of criteria (examples)
  - Strategic fit (weight %)
  - Cost / Total cost of ownership (weight %)
  - Implementation complexity (weight %)
  - Time to value / speed (weight %)
  - Performance / effectiveness (weight %)
  - Operational impact / maintainability (weight %)
  - Risk & compliance (weight %)
- Scoring scale and method
  - Example: 1–5 (1 = poor, 5 = excellent)
  - How weights and scores are combined (weighted average)

## 5. Methodology
- Data sources and evidence types used (e.g., pilots, vendor info, benchmarks)
- Who performed scoring (roles/teams)
- Any assumptions made
- Date of assessment

## 6. Comparative Assessment (summary)
- Provide a summary comparison (suggested table layout)
  - Columns: Option | Weighted score | Rank | High-level pros | High-level cons | Estimated cost
- Example row content (fill for each option)

## 7. Detailed Evaluation by Criterion
- For each criterion, provide:
  - Definition / what it measures
  - Rationale for importance
  - Scores for each option (with short justification)
  - Any relevant metrics or evidence
- Repeat subsections:
  - 7.1 Strategic fit
  - 7.2 Cost / TCO
  - 7.3 Implementation complexity
  - 7.4 Time to value
  - 7.5 Performance / effectiveness
  - 7.6 Operational impact
  - 7.7 Risk & compliance

## 8. Cost Analysis
- Summary of costs per option
  - Initial / capital costs
  - Recurring / operational costs (annual)
  - Cost assumptions and discount rate (if present value used)
- Simple TCO calculation (n-year)
- Break-even or payback analysis (if applicable)

## 9. Risk Assessment & Mitigation
- Top risks per option (list with likelihood and impact)
- Mitigation actions and residual risk
- Regulatory / compliance concerns

## 10. Sensitivity & Scenario Analysis
- Key variables tested (e.g., cost increases, slower adoption)
- How rankings change under different scenarios
- Robustness of recommendation

## 11. Qualitative Considerations
- Stakeholder preferences or political factors
- Vendor relationships / strategic dependencies
- Culture or skill alignment

## 12. Recommendation & Rationale
- Primary recommended option (clear statement)
- Rationale linking back to criteria and evidence
- Secondary (backup) option and when to choose it
- Conditions or triggers for reassessment

## 13. Implementation Considerations
- High-level implementation plan / timeline
- Key milestones and dependencies
- Resource requirements (people, skills, budget)
- Required approvals or decision points

## 14. Monitoring, KPIs & Review Plan
- Metrics to monitor success post-implementation
- Reporting cadence and owners
- Review and re-evaluation timeline

## 15. Appendices
- Raw scoring matrix (detailed scores and calculations)
- Data sources and references
- Full list of assumptions
- Detailed cost spreadsheets (or links)
- Glossary of terms

## Instructions for Use
- Populate Options Overview and Criteria first.
- Agree on weights with stakeholders before scoring.
- Use evidence-based scoring; document rationale for every score.
- Keep the executive summary concise and focused on decision-makers.

# Projektübersicht
- Projekttitel:
- Ziel(e): Kurzbeschreibung der Ziele für Marktforschung und Risikoidentifikation
- Hauptansprechpartner / Stakeholder:
- Zeitraum:
- Budgetrahmen:

# 1. Zielsetzung der Marktforschung
- Forschungsfragen / Hypothesen
- Entscheide, die durch die Forschung unterstützt werden sollen
- Erwartete Erkenntnisse / Nutzen

# 2. Forschungsmethodik: Marktforschung
## 2.1 Methodentypen
- Quantitativ:
  - Online-Umfragen, Telefonumfragen, Paneldaten, Sekundärdatenanalyse
- Qualitativ:
  - Tiefeninterviews, Fokusgruppen, Beobachtung, Ethnographie
- Sekundärforschung:
  - Branchenreports, Marktstudien, Wettbewerbsanalysen, öffentliche Daten

## 2.2 Stichprobe & Stichprobenplan
- Zielgruppe / Segmentierung
- Stichprobengröße und Selektionskriterien
- Rekrutierungsmethoden

## 2.3 Erhebungsinstrumente
- Fragebogen-Outline / Themenblöcke
- Interviewleitfaden (Kernausfragen)
- Messgrößen / KPIs (z. B. Awareness, Präferenz, Kaufabsicht)

## 2.4 Datenqualität & Validität
- Pretests / Pilotstudie
- Bias-Reduktion (z. B. Randomisierung, Filterfragen)
- Datenschutz & Einwilligung

## 2.5 Analyseplan
- Deskriptive Statistik, Segmentierung, Conjoint-Analyse, Trendanalysen
- Hypothesentests (z. B. Signifikanztests)
- Visualisierung & Reporting-Formate

## 2.6 Zeitplan & Meilensteine
- Instrumentenerstellung, Feldphase, Auswertung, Ergebnispräsentation

## 2.7 Deliverables Marktforschung
- Rohdaten / Datenbank
- Analysebericht (Executive Summary + Detailkapitel)
- Präsentation für Stakeholder
- Handlungsempfehlungen / Maßnahmenkatalog

# 3. Risikoidentifikation (bezogen auf Markt & Projekt)
## 3.1 Ziel der Risikoidentifikation
- Früherkennung relevanter Risiken zur Absicherung von Strategie und Umsetzung

## 3.2 Risikokategorien
- Markt- / Nachfragerisiken (z. B. Nachfragerückgang, Trendwechsel)
- Wettbewerbsrisiken (z. B. aggressive Preispolitik, neue Anbieter)
- Regulatorische / rechtliche Risiken
- Lieferketten- / Betriebsrisiken (z. B. Lieferantenausfall)
- Finanzielle Risiken (z. B. Cashflow, Kostenüberschreitung)
- Reputationsrisiken
- Technologische Risiken (z. B. Obsoleszenz)
- Datenschutz / IT-Sicherheitsrisiken

## 3.3 Methoden zur Identifikation
- Workshops mit Stakeholdern / Experteninterviews
- SWOT-Analyse
- PESTEL-Analyse (politisch, ökonomisch, sozial, technologisch, ökologisch, rechtlich)
- Szenario- und Sensitivitätsanalysen
- Checklisten & Lessons Learned aus früheren Projekten
- Monitoring externer Indikatoren (Branchenkennzahlen, Medienbeobachtung)

## 3.4 Risikobewertung
- Bewertungskriterien: Eintrittswahrscheinlichkeit vs. Auswirkung
- Scoring-Modell / Risikomatrix (Niedrig / Mittel / Hoch)
- Priorisierung nach Risikoexposure

## 3.5 Risikoreaktion & Maßnahmenplanung
- Strategien: Vermeiden, Reduzieren, Transferieren, Akzeptieren
- Konkrete Maßnahmen pro Risiko (Owner, Aktion, Frist, Ressourcen)
- Kosten-Nutzen-Abwägung der Maßnahmen

## 3.6 Monitoring & Reporting
- Frühwarnindikatoren / KPIs pro Risiko
- Reporting-Frequenz und Eskalationspfade
- Review-Zyklen (z. B. monatlich, quartalsweise)

## 3.7 Notfall- / Kontinuitätspläne
- Triggerbedingungen für Aktivierung
- Schritt-für-Schritt-Aktionspläne
- Kommunikationsplan (intern & extern)

# 4. Integration Marktforschung ↔ Risikoidentifikation
- Wie Marktforschungsergebnisse Risiken beeinflussen (z. B. Nachfrageänderungen)
- Feedback-Loop: Update der Risikoanalyse basierend auf Forschungsergebnissen
- Priorisierung von Risikomaßnahmen anhand empirischer Befunde

# 5. Rollen & Verantwortlichkeiten
- Projektleiter / Forschungsleiter
- Risikomanager / Risk Owner
- Datenspezialist / Analyst
- Stakeholder / Entscheidungsträger
- Externe Dienstleister (falls zutreffend)

# 6. Tools & Vorlagen
- Empfohlene Tools: Umfragesoftware, Statistiktools, Risk-Register-Template
- Checkliste für Feldphase
- Template für Risikoregister (Risiko, Kategorie, Wahrscheinlichkeit, Auswirkung, Score, Owner, Maßnahmen, Status)

# 7. Zeitplan & Budgetübersicht
- Grober Zeitplan mit Meilensteinen
- Budgetposten: Erhebung, Analyse, externe Beratungen, Contingency-Puffer

# 8. Deliverables & Abschluss
- Abgabeformate (Bericht, Präsentation, Daten)
- Abnahmebedingungen
- Nachbetrachtung / Lessons Learned

# Anhang: Kurze Checklisten
- Schnell-Check Marktforschung: Zielklarheit, Stichprobe ok, Instrumenten-Pretest, Datenschutz erfüllt
- Schnell-Check Risikoidentifikation: Alle Kategorien geprüft, Owner zugewiesen, Frühwarnindikatoren definiert

# Review Meeting — Conclusions First

## Meeting Summary (Conclusions & Key Decisions)
- Top-line conclusion(s):
  - [Concise statement of overall outcome or decision]
- Key decisions made:
  - Decision 1 — [short description]
  - Decision 2 — [short description]
- Immediate impacts / actions to expect:
  - [Impact 1]
  - [Impact 2]

## Action Items (Owner | Due Date | Priority | Status)
- Action 1 — Owner: [name] | Due: [date] | Priority: [H/M/L] | Status: [open/in progress/closed]
- Action 2 — Owner: [name] | Due: [date] | Priority: [H/M/L] | Status: [open/in progress/closed]
- (Add additional actions as needed)

## Attendees
- Present:
  - [Name — Role]
  - [Name — Role]
- Regrets / Absent:
  - [Name — Role]

## Meeting Context
- Meeting title: [Title]
- Date & time: [YYYY-MM-DD, HH:MM]
- Location / Call info: [physical room or link]
- Purpose / Objective:
  - [One-line objective or review scope]

## Agenda & Discussion Summary (by agenda item)
1. Agenda Item 1: [Title]
   - Summary: [Brief summary of discussion]
   - Key points raised:
     - [Point A]
     - [Point B]
   - Outcome: [Decision / next steps]
2. Agenda Item 2: [Title]
   - Summary: [Brief summary of discussion]
   - Key points raised:
     - [Point A]
     - [Point B]
   - Outcome: [Decision / next steps]
- (Repeat for each agenda item)

## Metrics, Results, or Evidence Reviewed
- Metric / Report 1: [value / trend / conclusion]
- Metric / Report 2: [value / trend / conclusion]
- Attachments / links:
  - [Document name — link]

## Risks, Issues, and Concerns
- Open issue 1: [description — impact — owner]
- Risk 1: [description — likelihood — mitigation]
- Decisions needed / outstanding questions:
  - [Question 1 — owner to resolve by date]

## Dependencies & Constraints
- Dependency 1: [external team / date / impact]
- Constraint 1: [budget / timeline / resource limitation]

## Next Steps & Follow-up
- Short-term next steps:
  - [Action — owner — due date]
- Who will follow up and by when:
  - [Name — responsibility — check-in date]
- Proposed date/time for next review:
  - [YYYY-MM-DD, HH:MM] (tentative)

## Notes / Additional Context
- Miscellaneous notes:
  - [Note 1]
  - [Note 2]

## Appendix / Supporting Documents
- [Document 1 — link/file reference]
- [Document 2 — link/file reference]

Customer Call Notes Template

- Call details
  - Date: [YYYY-MM-DD]
  - Time: [HH:MM, timezone]
  - Duration: [mins]
  - Channel: [phone / video / in-person]
  - Call owner / recorder: [Name]

- Participants
  - Customer: [Name — Role — Company]
  - Internal: [Name — Role]
  - Additional attendees: [List]

- Purpose / Objective
  - [Brief purpose of the call]

- One-line summary
  - [Concise summary sentence]

- Key discussion points
  - [Point 1 — short note]
  - [Point 2 — short note]
  - [Point 3 — short note]

- Decisions made
  - [Decision 1 — rationale — effective date/owner]
  - [Decision 2 — ...]

- Action items
  - [ ] Action: [task] — Owner: [Name] — Due: [YYYY-MM-DD] — Status: [Not started / In progress / Done]
  - [ ] Action: [task] — Owner: [Name] — Due: [YYYY-MM-DD] — Status: [ ]

- Open issues / blockers
  - Issue: [description] — Impact: [high/med/low] — Owner: [Name] — Next step: [ ]

- Customer requests / requirements
  - [Request 1 — details / priority]
  - [Request 2 — details / priority]

- Risks & concerns
  - [Risk description] — Likelihood: [ ] — Mitigation: [ ]

- Agreements & next steps
  - [Deliverable / responsibility / expected delivery date]
  - Next meeting: [Date / Time / Purpose]

- Follow-ups required
  - [Who will follow up, with what, by when]

- Attachments / links
  - [Link to recording, deck, ticket, docs]

- Customer sentiment / tone
  - [Positive / Neutral / Concerned — notes]

- Additional notes / context
  - [Any background details or nuances]

- Prepared by / Last updated
  - Prepared by: [Name]
  - Last updated: [YYYY-MM-DD]

signature.instructions:
Generate a summary template based on user requirements.

If the user does not specify formatting requirements,
generate a structured outline using Markdown headers (#, ##)
and bullet points.

fields.description: User input containing either keywords or a descriptive paragraph
By default, generate a structured outline using Markdown headers (#, ##) and bullet points unless the user explicitly specifies alternative formatting requirements.
